Posted: March 4, 2015
												I do not know many games that tried to emulate and challenge the original master of the line tower defence, Plants vs. Zombies (PvZ). Battle Ranch takes the same basic principle and, frankly, merely does it again. They should have at least made the turrets something else than fruits. Still, there are some differences for its own merit.Every level throws a bunch of different zomb... uh, I mean freaking boar vikings at the ranch and you have to defend it by planting defensive turrets. There are both fast-loading pea shooters and burst turrets with longer reload-times, turrets with slowing capabilities, debuffers and outright defensive plants that block enemy movement or projectiles from hitting your plants. There are single-use items like bear traps and different area-attack bombs all the way to the slowly replenishing banana missile silo. Mobs sometimes drop special single-use items as well. Defences are no real innovation in tower defence but adequate enough.There is a good variety of different enemies from the basic grunt through more enduring varieties to ones with special abilities like flying, fast moving capabilities or tunneling under everything. There are several tanks too. Alas, within these special capabilities the boars do not differ more - every boar of a certain special type looks and behaves always exactly the same way. It would have been nice to see some variation or maybe stronger or weaker types of the specific specialities. However, noting that almost all the game graphics files are plain images, some crazy graphics mods might become available in time.Different from PvZ the six-row field is divided into two separate parts: the garden and the turret field. Field hosts your defensive capabilities while in the garden you play a constant mini-game of planting and harvesting fruit for score that's used to buy turrets. There are 18 different garden plants, one for each turret type. They differ from each other with their reharvesting times and score production rates, and in addition few of them have to be replanted after harvesting. You get a full score (i.e. a star) from a level if you harvest all of the fruits required by the level.One thing that's nice is that you don't have to click every single fruit you harvest - simple slide by the mouse cursor is enough. However, annoyingly enough the frame rate appears to be locked to 15 FPS, resulting in clunky animations. Also, the PC port (Battle Ranch was originally a phone/tablet game) has merely one resolution available, which is a huge oversight. The early levels are also super-easy so I'd wish there was a turbo button to speed things up. That or it should generally be slightly faster paced. Also, you can't redo levels: you have to play through the whole thing again if you miss a star for that season perfection achievement.The story mode has 50 levels divided into five seasons (the regular ones + unpredictable) plus a couple of special levels for each season. The only differences between the regular seasons are the fruits and the obstacles that you have to clear to fill the whole garden: grass, stones, tree stumps and snow are just reskins of the same stuff, as are the "tools" required to clear/harvest them. In the unpredictable season and bonus levels between stages some special effects can affect the garden and your plants, like rain grows more grass to block the garden (minor annoyance) or localized tornados destroy plants in random locations. Unpredictable season is clearly the most challenging (and suitably, the last one) of the otherwise easy story seasons.After story you can hurl yourself into the bonus games and mini games: there's a pure gardening mode and a long defence mode with several stages of enemies with the same fruit defenders. It's a shame there were often just one or two levels of the more intriguing mini games like the one where the field is filled with treasure chests, each one containing either a boar or a weapon to use againts them, a click opening the surprise. Myself, I found the puzzle levels of Boarmania the most interesting, for in those the roles are reversed: you are given a set amount of boars and you have to destroy the gardens behind rows of defensive plants. There were 15 levels of these but I wouldn't have minded having more.Like any farming game, this one also has a silly garden for you to waste hours with. Any garden plants can be planted there with a set fee and you'll get some money for the plants thus harvested. This is probably the most viable way to get the two grindy achievements (get 1 million dollars and harvest 100000 fruits). Fortunately, you can hire a slow-walking but tireless farming gnome to do the harvesting for you and let the game run on the background while you play something else. Nevertheless, it's still going to take a lot of time if you want them. I've effectively AFKed some 50 hours of my game time and silently grinded the fruits in the background while actually hacking away at knights or ruling vast kingdoms elsewhere. Oh, and there's also a barn with potential (and quite expensive) cows and chickens and stuff but I figured it was a waste of grinding time to grow chow for animals (unintentional shout-out to vegetarianism).In effect, there's about 30 hours of real playing involved. I'd call it Above Average and in my opinion it's worth its list price of 7 euros especially if you loved PvZ, maybe about half that if tower defence still tickles your fun bones. The oversights in porting it to PC dull the outlook, though the devs have said they are at least looking into the resolution matter. Modding might make it more interesting even though there's no Steam Workshop at the time or (AFAIK) planned out.If you're sceptical whether you'd like it, there's a demo on the game's Steam Store Page. Initially I tried it and was satisfied to buy it at launch, but it's also a good way to see whether you can put up with the resolution, clunky animations and the similarities to PvZ. It's convenient that you can continue the full version from where you were left in the demo.

Battle Ranch: Pigs vs Plants exemplifies how a good concept still needs to be well-handled to make a good game.  This is a blatant clone of the wildly successful Plants vs Zombies with Viking Pigs in place of the Zombies.  And it's dull.Beyond the basic and familiar plant-based lane defense segments, Battle Ranch has a bunch of additional features to offer -- animals to keep in barns, plants to grow in a greenhouse -- but you need the patience of Job to unlock any of it because the game is so horribly slow.  The attackers plod their way towards you, while your plants lackadaisically fire at them.  Every level seems to take forever.  It's slow, it's tiresome, and it's unchallenging.  Maybe after enough hours invested, Battle Ranch will pick up the pace and actually become fun.  I won't be finding out.  I've already given it a tedious hour of my life, and I don't trust it with any more.

												Battle Ranch: Pigs vs Plants rests in a subgenre of Defense games that is most often represented by Plants vs Zombies, which I'm embarrassed to admit, I still have yet to play.  Even so, that shouldn't keep us from discussing Battle Ranch on its own merit.  Because, even though it's not a game I would have actively sought out, thanks to Epic Quest Games, I was given the opportunity to play Pigs vs Plants to create my own opinionn of a game which receives very little hype.  Having been a steadfast fan of defense games since the iconic Defense Grid: Awakening came out, Pigs vs Plants comes as my introduction to this style of defense games where you play on a game board and enemies move from one side of the field in order to destroy your resources and reach your base at the close end of the field.  It might be thought of as simpler to the full field style Defense games, but not without a similar brand of frantic pace in getting your own defenses in shape in preparation for the onslaught.  You still have different types of towers, even if they aren't upgradable, and tools to slow and stop the enemies.  The other element that isn't present in traditional defense games is how your resources are generated.  You must plant crops and harvest them, rather than generating points by killing enemies.  This adds to the exceitment by giving you the additional dimension of managing your crops.  Not only are there a number of towers at your disposal, this is also a pretty good variety of tools, and an in game store that allows you to buy tools, unit slots, and other things that come in useful to help you fend of the enemies.When you first start the game, one of the more notable aspects is the art style.  It has a comical, fun style that is easy to appreciate, even if not ground-breaking.  I have to give credit to Playboom, an unknown developer for putting together something that is fun, challenging, is incredibly addictive, all for a remarkably low price of $1.99.If you're looking for some mindless entertainment and don't require something that represents the high bar of technology, you might just want to give Battle Ranch: Pigs vs Plants a try.  For all of the things that it does right ?I recommend it.  My final score is a 7/10.

												Alright, so to be fair, I managed to nab this game for free from galagiveaways, however I'll try my best not to let that influence my review by any means.The game comes across as being a PvZ clone based on what you'd see, but there's actually a lot of differences that made it stand out to me. First and foremost, you can't just plant down your growth plants and expect them to instantly generate your resources. You end up having to water them first, which adds to another level of management, aside from placement of defenses. In addition to that, there appears to be a mechanic that involves collecting a certain number of fruit or vegetables from those plants in order to get a star for each level, though to be honest I'm not entirely sure what that adds aside from a sense of completion.The watering mechanic seems to come further into play during later stages of the game from what I can tell, and... Well, actually makes for an interestingly frantic gameplay compared to the relatively slow looking animation of the pigs you're fighting. There's a lot to keep track of at once, but it never feels too disorienting, just... Like there's a lot to do and keep track of which is actually pretty good.So, if I can edit, I will once I get further into the game, I'm only up to the level at which the player can unlock the greenhouse, so please bear with me for now. The greenhouse is about what you'd imagine from similar games, allowing the player to generate some coins and... In my opinion being a rather fun gameplay mechanic, but more likely than not that opinion stems from my appreciation of idle/incremental gaming.So far, I'd give this game a 7/10, it's not perfect, the animations feel somewhat awkward in places and the art style isn't necessarily the most pleasing, but the gameplay itself is really solid and it's definitely worth picking up if you're a fan of similar games. Seriously though, it feels like there's a lot of content I'm missing, all things considered, so it's safe to say it's pretty packed with enough to keep you entertained for a while.Thank you for reading if you did, and sorry for this being so drawn out.

												This game is just plain horrible. It is slow, uninteresting, and a bad copy paste of Plants vs Zombies. But it's super-cheap. The question is: Do you prefer to pay a few euros for an interesting game really worth playing to, or a few cents for a shear loss of your precious lifetime? The background story is that viking wild boars are invading some land, and there is no one to defend it but vegetables. Sounds exciting. The game is made of a giant courtyard, and you can plant your vegetables (which come in various kinds, just like there are various towers in a tower defense game, which tis one basically is) on rows. Your foes will attack these rows, so you have to defend everyone of them to keep the enemies from coming. In the backyard you can make some vegetables growing to win some kind of money. You have to plant their seeds and pour water in them once, it's quite boring. What really kills the game is the pace. The first few minutes you just have to wait until your vegetables grow. Then the waves start coming but they are very slow in their moves. It's so boring that it's hard not being distracted away from your screen (by the wall next to you, for instance, which is so much more interesting).
